byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE  and N. R. KLEINFIELD

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Feb. 27 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer considers Theodore Roosevelt a political role model, but he has shown that he is not one to speak softly even as he carries a big stick.

headline.main: Why Spitzer Succeeded Where Pataki Fell Short
headline.print_headline: Why Spitzer Succeeded Where Pataki Fell Short

docs.snippet: ALBANY, Feb. 27 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer considers Theodore Roosevelt a political role model, but he has shown that he is not one to speak softly even as he carries a big stick.

docs.lead_paragraph: After years of stalemates and false starts, New York leaders yesterday announced a far-reaching deal to overhaul the state's much-criticized workers' compensation system by significantly increasing the weekly benefits that go to injured workers while cracking down on employers who cheat the system. Gov. Eliot Spitzer hailed the deal, reached with legislative, business and labor leaders, as an important improvement to the business climate in the state. Many companies have complained that the cost of workers' compensation insurance has grown too high, and some manufacturers said they were paying more than $2 per hour per worker in premiums.

headline.main: Deal in Albany Overhauls Pay For Worker Aid

docs.abstract: Gov Eliot Spitzer and New York legislative, business and labor leaders announce far-reaching deal to overhaul state's much-criticized workers' compensation system by significantly increasing weekly benefits to injured workers, while cracking down on employers who cheat system; Spitzer sees gain for business climate on issue that some companies say pushes them out of New York; premiums are among nation's highest, while worker benefits are very low; current $400 weekly maximum will rise to $650; Spitzer, who made concessions that Gov George Pataki had refused, sees win for all parties; deal affecting 8.6 million workers aims to cut costs by limiting number of years some workers receive benefits and by creating fee schedule for drugs, tests and prosthetic devices; projects $500 million in annual savings, yielding 10-15 percent cut in premiums; antifraud squad to double in size to uncover employers who underreport work force, do not cover workers or misclassify them as contractors; partially disabled workers will be capped at up to 525 weeks of benefits instead of until retirement age; photo; map and graphs on benefits around nation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Iraqi Cabinet Approves Guidelines on Oil Revenue The Iraqi cabinet approved a draft of a law that would set guidelines for nationwide distribution of oil revenues and foreign investment in the oil industry. The endorsement marked a major agreement among the country's ethnic and sectarian political blocs on one of Iraq's most divisive issues. A1 An explosion inside the Ministry of Public Works wounded an Iraqi vice president and the public works minister in what officials described as a possible assassination attempt. A8 Bosnia Killings Ruled Genocide The International Court of Justice for the first time called the massacres of Bosnian Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995 a genocide, but determined that Serbia itself was not guilty of the enormous crime. Nonetheless, it said Serbia should have prevented the genocide and punished the Bosnian Serbs who killed close to 8,000 men and boys in July 1995. A1 Foreigners Killed in Saudi Arabia Gunmen killed three French citizens and wounded a fourth near the holy city of Medina in Saudi Arabia in a brazen reminder that attacks on foreigners there have not stopped despite an aggressive three-year security crackdown. A6 Pakistan Rejects U.S. Criticism Pakistan said it would not ''accept dictation'' after Vice President Dick Cheney delivered a stiff message to President Pervez Musharraf, warning him that aid to Pakistan could be in jeopardy if he did not improve his country's effectiveness in combating Al Qaeda and the Taliban. A9 NATIONAL A10-16 Clash Over Spending On Child Health Program Governors clashed with the White House over the future of the popular Children's Health Insurance Program, an issue that some members of both parties said was as important as money for the war in Iraq. A1 Claims of Finding Jesus' Bones A new documentary by the Discovery Channel claims to provide evidence that a crypt unearthed 27 years ago in Jerusalem contained the bones of Jesus of Nazareth. A10 Juror Dismissed in Leak Case The judge presiding over the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. dismissed one of the jurors in the midst of deliberations and ruled that the case should go forward with the remaining 11-member jury. A14 Loan Agency Under Fire Responding to criticism of slow response after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, the Small Business Administration, which provides most long-term rebuilding aid to disaster victims, accelerated its lending to homeowners and businesses in the Gulf region. But now federal investigators are looking into accusations that the agency made thousands of loans without following its own rules to avoid fraud. A10 Asians in California Politics California's 4.4 million Asians constitute the state's second-largest ethnic group and the largest Asian population in the country, but they have been underrepresented in elected office. Now they are moving beyond fund-raising, where they have long been a force, to elect representatives of their own. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 English-Language Classes Lack Space and Financing As immigrants increasingly settle away from large urban centers -- 225,000 have landed in New York's suburbs since 2000, compared with 44,000 in the city -- many are waiting months or even years to get into government-financed English classes, which are often overcrowded and lack textbooks. A1 No Cap to Ferry Claims A federal judge rejected New York City's attempt to use an obscure 19th-century maritime law to cap its liability in the 2003 crash of a Staten Island ferry at $14 million. The judge ruled that the 1851 law did not apply if the city's managers had been negligent, as he found they had been. B1 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Canada's move to restore rights; game with no winner; a bad report card; you want some truth with that? Columns: Ann Althouse, Nicholas D. Kristof. SPORTSTUESDAY D1-6 Ullrich Retires From Cycling Jan Ullrich, the cyclist who elevated and then crushed his sport's profile in his native Germany, announced his retirement from competitive racing. Last year, he was denied entry in the Tour de France after his name surfaced in a Spanish doping investigation. D2 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 A Mystery in Vanishing Bees In 24 states, beekeepers have noticed that their bees have been disappearing inexplicably at an alarming rate, and growers are becoming nervous about the ability of the commercial bee industry to meet the demand for bees to pollinate dozens of crops. A1 Business Digest C2 Crossword E6 TV Listings E9 Weather A12
